channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Biden’s National Security Strategy Focuses on China, Russia and Democracy at Home
item.description: The document, which every new administration is required to issue, was delayed last winter as it became clear that Russia’s invasion of Ukraine was imminent.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: In his strategy document, President Biden returned to a theme he has established since his second month in office, describing a coming struggle as one of autocracies versus democracies.

item.title: Brittney Griner Is Struggling in Russian Prison, Her Lawyer Says
item.description: Facing nine years in prison in Russia, the U.S. basketball star is struggling emotionally and worried that a swap deal to release her may not materialize, according to one of her attorneys.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Brittney Griner at a court outside Moscow in August. The United States has said that her detention and trial were politically motivated.

item.title: Leonard Leo Pushed the Courts Right. Now He’s Aiming at American Society.
item.description: After leading efforts to put conservatives on the bench, the activist has quietly built a sprawling network and raised huge sums of money to challenge liberal values.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth P. Vogel
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: Leonard A. Leo’s influence on the right stems largely from the credibility he built with donors and politicians during his decades-long crusade to give conservatives power in federal courts.

item.title: Leonard Leo’s Network Is Increasingly Powerful. But It Is Not Easy to Define.
item.description: The groups in the network spent nearly $504 million on policy and political fights, including grants to about 150 allied groups, between mid-2015 and last year.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth P. Vogel
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: Leonard A. Leo’s network is made up of overlapping and evolving nonprofit and for-profit groups that make it difficult to define and analyze.

item.title: US Considers Easing Sanctions on Venezuela as Migration Surges
item.description: The Biden administration may allow the last American company producing oil in Venezuela to resume exports if the Maduro government takes steps to restore democracy.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Venezuelan family crossing the Darién Gap between Colombia and Panama last month.

item.title: Death on the Border: Were Twin Brothers Hunting Migrants or Wildlife?
item.description: When two migrants were shot on a roadside in West Texas, the police arrested two suspects: The warden of a troubled private prison, and his brother, a local jail employee.
item.media:credit: Ivan Pierre Aguirre for The New York Times

item.title: Liz Truss Stirs Uncertainty Over the U.K.’s Economic Plans
item.description: Prime Minister Liz Truss appeared to rule out cuts in public spending, as doubts about the fiscal soundness of the government’s program continued to roil the markets.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Liz Truss leaving to address Parliament on Wednesday.

item.title: Turmoil Returns to the U.K. Bond Market
item.description: The Bank of England started a bond-buying program last month to stabilize financial markets. But its plan to end the program this Friday is only making investors more nervous.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison
item.media:description: To calm markets, the Bank of England made a forceful intervention in September, undertaking large-scale purchases of British government bonds.

item.title: Federal Reserve Officials Worried About Risks of Faster Inflation at Last Meeting
item.description: Minutes from the Fed’s September meeting showed many were more worried about doing too little to control inflation than too much.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:description: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, at a news conference last month, after the central bank raised interest rates by three-quarters of a percentage point for a third straight time.

item.title: Uvalde Shooting Investigation Miscast Blame For Delayed Police Response
item.description: The school police chief was singled out for blame, but a Times visual investigation found that scores of trained officers, including those from an elite Border Patrol unit, took many of the same steps.
item.dc:creator: Robin Stein and Alexander Cardia

item.title: Los Angeles Confronts Racial Divide Anew After Leak of Racist Comments
item.description: Scores of residents demanded that three City Council members resign — as did President Biden — over a secretly recorded conversation that involved racist insults and slurs.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan and Shawn Hubler
item.media:credit: Sarah Reingewirtz/The Orange County Register, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Mike Bonin, a member of the Los Angeles City Council, shed tears on Tuesday as he spoke about the racist comments directed toward his son.

item.title: Hasidic School Is Breaking State Education Law, N.Y. Official Rules
item.description: Issued amid a lawsuit brought by a parent who left the community, the determination could pose a significant challenge to Hasidic Jewish schools.
item.dc:creator: Eliza Shapiro and Brian M. Rosenthal
item.media:description: Yeshiva Mesivta Arugath Habosem, an all-boys Hasidic school in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is not complying with a state education law requiring private schools to offer basic secular studies.

item.title: Under the Skin of Jamie Lee Curtis
item.description: Whether it’s her return to her horror roots in “Halloween Ends” or her buzzy performance in “Everything Everywhere All at Once,” freedom is what the actress is after.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan
item.media:credit: Ryan Pfluger for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I feel all the feels, all the time,” Jamie Lee Curtis said.

item.title: MacArthur Foundation Announces 25 New ‘Genius’ Grant Winners
item.description: The 2022 awards are going to artists, activists, scholars, scientists and others who have shown “exceptional creativity.” The grants are a bit bigger than before: $800,000 over five years.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens
item.category: MacArthur, John D and Catherine T, Foundation

item.title: American Culture Is Trash Culture
item.description: It’s not just that trash is what Americans want from movies; it’s who we are. So where did it go?
item.dc:creator: Wesley Morris

item.title: Haiti Has Been a Plaything of Powerful Forces for Too Long
item.description: Haiti is in crisis. If the U.S. wants to help, it needs to get out of the way.
item.dc:creator: Lydia Polgreen
item.media:credit: Richard Pierrin/Agence France-Presse, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Protesters demanding the resignation of Ariel Henry, Haiti’s acting prime minister, set fires in the streets of Port-au-Prince this month.

item.title: With Attacks, Russia’s Putin Is Trying to Terrorize Ukrainians
item.description: Among Ukrainians, there is an almost palpable feeling that Russia is losing the war.
item.dc:creator: Margo Gontar

item.title: The ‘Sleeping Giant’ That May Decide the Midterms
item.description: The choices made by Latino voters will be crucial to the outcome in a disproportionate share of Senate battleground states and key House races.
item.dc:creator: Thomas B. Edsall
item.media:credit: Verónica G. Cárdenas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Monica De La Cruz, the Republican candidate in Texas’ 15th Congressional District, at a rally in McAllen, Texas.

item.title: What a MacArthur Foundation ‘Genius Grant’ Gave Me
item.description: The award is about so much more than money and secrecy.
item.dc:creator: Tressie McMillan Cottom
item.category: MacArthur, John D and Catherine T, Foundation
item.media:credit: Roger Kisby for The New York Times

item.title: The Most Ridiculous Part of the L.A. City Council President’s Apology
item.description: Motherhood and racism aren’t compatible? If only it were that easy.
item.dc:creator: Frank Bruni
item.media:credit: Al Seib/Los Angeles Times, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The former Los Angeles City Council president Nury Martinez.

item.title: Is America Headed for Another Civil War?
item.description: Jamelle Bouie and Tim Alberta on whether America’s polarization is at a tipping point.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Argument’

item.title: In Defense of the Mom Group
item.description: An interview with Helena Andrews-Dyer about her new book, “The Mamas.”
item.dc:creator: Jessica Grose

item.title: Abortion Bans Weigh on Republicans
item.description: Banning abortion is weighing on the party.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times

item.title: A Bridge, a Bomb and Putin’s Revenge
item.description: The Russian missile barrage on Ukraine reveals Moscow’s narrowing options.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise, Rob Szypko, Nina Feldman, Diana Nguyen, Mooj Zadie, John Ketchum, Liz O. Baylen, Lisa Chow, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto and Corey Schreppel
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Damage from a missile strike in Zaporizhzhia, Ukraine, this week. The rocket attacks left neighborhoods across the country battered and bloodied.

item.title: We Were Three
item.description: A story of lies, family, America and what Covid revealed, as well as what it destroyed. All three parts arrive on Thursday, Oct. 13.
item.dc:creator: Nancy Updike, Jenelle Pifer, Julie Snyder and Sophie Allison of Soccer Mommy

item.title: Is Ron DeSantis as Strong a Potential Candidate as He Seems?
item.description: The Florida governor looks to be well positioned to head into a hypothetical presidential primary in 2024. But past Republican darlings rose just as fast — only to fall quickly.
item.dc:creator: Blake Hounshell
item.media:credit: Taylor Glascock for The New York Times
item.media:description: In polls, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida consistently rates as the second choice of Republican voters, behind former President Donald Trump but well ahead of any putative rivals.

item.title: Navy Report on SEAL Trainee’s Death Details Medics’ Failure to Help Him
item.description: Seaman Kyle Mullen’s death a few hours after completing the brutal Hell Week portion of the SEALs’ selection course raised broad concerns about how the course is run.
item.dc:creator: Dave Philipps
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Angela Lansbury, Broadway’s Beloved Everywoman
item.description: She performed without sentimentality or histrionics, embodying the full range of human joy and depravity while remaining professional and approachable.
item.dc:creator: Jesse Green
item.media:description: “I absorb everything,” Angela Lansbury told Jesse Green in 2007. She needed to play many different kinds of characters, he writes, to make the best yield of all she’d observed.

item.title: A Nonbinary Runner’s Experience of the Chicago Marathon
item.description: “A big part of being here and running this race is reclaiming this place, which left me with a lot of emotional scars,” Cal Calamia said of running the Chicago Marathon in their hometown.
item.dc:creator: Kurt Streeter and Taylor Glascock

item.title: Protests in Iran Spread, Including to Oil Sector, Despite Violent Crackdown
item.description: Human rights groups say at least 185 people have been killed and thousands injured or arrested, but demonstrations that began after the death of Mahsa Amini have continued nearly a month.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Jane Arraf
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Health Panel Recommends Screening All Kids 8 and Up for Anxiety
item.description: To address the mental health crisis facing American youth, experts also said adolescents should be screened for depression.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson
item.category: United States Preventive Services Task Force

item.title: Can You Drink On Antidepressants? What Experts Say About Safety.
item.description: The internet is full of warnings about antidepressants and drinking. Here’s what mental health experts want you to know.
item.dc:creator: Jyoti Madhusoodanan
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: Can Stimulating the Vagus Nerve Improve Mental Health?
item.description: On social media, exercises that aim to “tone” one of our body’s longest nerves have been touted as a cure-all for anxiety and other psychological ailments. Here’s what the research says.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron

item.title: How You Can Use Anticipation to Enjoy Life More
item.description: Looking forward to something can be almost as good as experiencing it.
item.dc:creator: Holly Burns

item.title: Virtual Reality Therapy Could Give Relief to Seniors
item.description: Some care facilities are giving older adults a way to visit their pasts to boost their well-being.
item.dc:creator: Matt Fuchs

item.title: Melissa Etheridge and Jill Sobule Bring Their Whole Lives to the Stage
item.description: They both first made a splash in the ’90s. They’re now in New York to present new theatrical memoirs that mix storytelling and songs.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli
item.category: My Window -- A Journey Through Life (Play)
item.media:credit: Luisa Opalesky for The New York Times
item.media:description: Melissa Etheridge, left, and Jill Sobule. In the 1990s, when Etheridge released the hits “Come to My Window” and “I’m the Only One,” she made a splash. That same decade, Jill Sobule released “I Kissed a Girl.”

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
